Aristotle.passage: Aristotle (/ˌɛrɪˈθjuːləti/; Greek: Ἀristóteles, romanized: Aristotélēs; 384 – 322 BC) was a Greek philosopher, scientist, student of Plato, and founder of the Lyceum. He is best known for his philosophical works, particularly the "Metaphysics", "Nicomachean Ethics", and "Rhetoric", all of which have had significant influence on Western philosophy and science. Born on 384 BC on the Greek island of Stageira to a prominent family, Aristotle was orphaned at age eight and raised by his grandfather, who had been a student of Plato. At the age of seventeen he joined Plato's Academy in Athens, where he studied under such prominent scholars as Eudoxus of Cnidus and Speusippus, and became Plato's most prominent student and successor. Aristotle traveled widely and wrote over one hundred and fifty works, including treatises on biology, zoology, meteorology, mineralogy, logic, and physics, as well as books on poetry, rhetoric, and ethics. In the words of his biographer, "Aristotle was the master of those who came after him, the founder of a school that dominated the teaching of philosophy down to the Middle Ages, and the author of books that were studied more than two thousand years after his death."

qae_pairs.explanation: Aristotle was born on the Greek island of Stageira.

Augustine of Hippo.passage: In the early fifth century, Augustine of Hippo (354–430), a Christian bishop, developed a theory of the fall of Adam and the redemption of humanity through the death and resurrection of Jesus. His theory, known as "the doctrine of original sin", was a key element in the development of Western Christianity. Augustine was born in 354 in Tagaste, a small town in what is today Algeria. His father, Patricius, was a Roman citizen of Berber origin, and his mother, Saint Monica, was of Italian descent. His parents were devout Christians, and they taught him to speak Latin, the language of the Roman Empire, at an early age. He was baptized as a baby and grew up speaking both Latin and Greek. In 386, Augustine moved to Carthage, where, at the age of twenty, he became a Manichean. In the summer of 386, Augustine had a vision in his garden that he described as "a light from heaven". He converted to Catholicism and, in 387, he was ordained a deacon. He was later ordained a priest. Augustine was elected bishop of Hippo Regius, a position he occupied from 395 to his death in 430. He is considered one of the most significant and influential Christian theologians and philosophers in the history of the Catholic Church. He is also recognized as one of the greatest religious thinkers of all time.

Benedict of Nursia.passage: Benedict of Nursia (Latin: Benito, Ital. [ˈbɛntiːto]; c. 480 – 550), also known as Saint Benedict or Saint Beneto, was an Italian monk and priest. He is the founder of Western monasticism. Benedict was born in Norcia, Umbria, to a noble family. His father was Proculus, a consul and senator of Rome. His mother's name was Felicity, and he had a younger brother named Florentius. In the year 500, he was invited to become the Abbot of the monastery of Subiaco by its then abbot, Evagrius. The monastery was located on the side of a mountain, and was in a state of disrepair. Benedict rebuilt the monastery, and in so doing, established a monastic order. The rule he developed, which was later called the Benedictine Rule, became the model for Western monasticism. The Benedictine Order spread throughout Western Europe and beyond, and the monasteries founded in his name became centers of learning and culture. He died in the year 549 at the monastery of Subiaco. The Catholic Church celebrates Benedict's feast day on July 17, the day of his death.

Boethius.passage: The Consolation of Philosophy (Latin: Consolatio Philosophiae) is a book written in 524 by the Roman philosopher and Christian theologian Boethius. It was written as a consolation to himself and his family, in prison and under sentence of death, for having supposedly made a political statement against the emperor, and for having supposedly conspired against the emperor. The Consolation of Philosophy is an ancient work of literature, written in Latin hexameters. It is divided into five books, and is written in the form of a letter from the imprisoned Boethius to his friend, the Roman senator Symmachus, who was also imprisoned at the time. In the Consolation, Boethius seeks to console himself and his family for their loss, and to explain his own philosophy of the Consolation of Philosophy, which is based on the works of Aristotle and Cicero. The Consolation of Philosophy has had an immense influence on Western literature and culture, and has inspired many works of literature and philosophy since its original writing. It is considered a key work of medieval literature and philosophy, and one of the most important works of Latin literature. Boethius was born around 480 in Rome, into an ancient family of the Roman nobility. His father, who died when Boethius was very young, was a senator, and his grandfather had been a noted Roman general.

qae_pairs.explanation: Boethius was born in Rome.

qae_pairs.explanation: The Consolation of Philosophy

Cicero.passage:
1.1 Cicero's family 

Cicero was the son of a Roman eques, Marcus Tullius Cicero, who came from a wealthy and politically connected family, and his wife, Terentia, née Claudia Quinta (d.c. 45 BC). Cicero had a sister, Tullia, who was married to a man named Gaius Verres, who was eventually prosecuted by Cicero. Cicero also had a brother, Quintus, who was a year older than he was. Cicero's family was well-known throughout Rome. His father was a famous lawyer, and his uncle, Quintus, was elected consul of the Roman Republic in 137 BC. Cicero's family belonged to the equestrian order. This was the highest class of Roman citizens, and it was from this order that the emperor was chosen. Cicero, however, was born free, and was therefore a Roman citizen. Cicero had a good education for a Roman citizen of his time and place. He was taught Greek and Latin by private tutors, and he studied philosophy and rhetoric under a famous teacher, the orator Marcus Cato. Cato was a strict disciplinarian, but he taught Cicero how to speak effectively in public, and he was also the first man to introduce Cicero to the writings of the Greek philosophers.

qae_pairs.question: What is the name of Cicero's wife?
qae_pairs.explanation: Terentia

qae_pairs.question: Who was the teacher of Cicero?
qae_pairs.explanation: Marcus Cato was a strict disciplinarian, but he taught Cicero how to speak effectively in public, and he was also the first man to introduce Cicero to the writings of the Greek philosophers.

Confucius.passage: The Analects of Confucius (Chinese: 論語, "Lun Yu") is a collection of sayings, anecdotes and personal remarks attributed to Kong Qiu ("Master Kong") or Kong Gong (Confucius), the founder of Confucianism. The work is a compilation of sayings and conversations of Kong, who was a teacher and a politician in the state of Lu, in the Spring and Autumn Period of ancient China. It consists of around 50,000 Chinese characters and is divided into 54 books, which are grouped into 9 sections according to their content. The work has had a profound and enduring influence on East Asian culture. The Analects is traditionally ascribed to Kong, who is said to have compiled it after his death, although modern scholarship has questioned this. The work was first compiled in the early Han Dynasty, and the first complete version is traditionally dated to 239 BCE. The book is traditionally attributed to Confucius's grandson Kong An, but this is a later attribution. The book itself contains no information about the authorship of the work. It was not until after the Han dynasty that the work became a central part of Confucius's legacy. The book is a compilation of Confucius's conversations and sayings, recorded by his students. It is a primary record of his teachings and ideas.

qae_pairs.question: Which religion was founded by Kong Qiu?
qae_pairs.explanation: Kong Qiu was a teacher and a politician in the state of Lu, in the Spring and Autumn Period of ancient China. He was the founder of Confucianism.

David.passage: David (Hebrew: דָּוִד david "belonging to (Yahweh)"; Greek: Δαβδαβος Dábdos) is a Biblical and Quranic figure. The name means "belonging to (or chosen by) God". In the Hebrew Bible, he appears as a major character in the Book of Samuel and in the Book of Chronicles. In the Hebrew Bible, David is the second king of the United Kingdom of Israel and Judah, and the fourth king of Israel, after Saul, Solomon, and Jeroboam. In the Book of Kings, he is a major character, but the Book of Chronicles, which covers the same events, focuses on him more. He was a warrior and leader who established Jerusalem as the capital of the united monarchy, and he defeated the Philistines, the Moabites, Edomites, and Ammonites. His reign is considered a golden age in the Hebrew Bible, with the building of Jerusalem's First Temple, the establishment of the city's fortifications, and the unification of the Israelites under a single monarchy. David is also a major character and the central figure in the Hebrew Bible's Book of Samuel. He is a young man from Bethlehem in Judah. He is shepherd of his father Jesse's sheep, but is chosen by the Lord to be king.

Diocletian.passage: Diocletian (Latin: "Diocles", "Diocletianus", "Diocles August" ; Greek: "Διογέλας" "Dio-ke-las", "Dio-ke-le-as" ; c. 245 – c. 316), born Diocles, was Roman Emperor from AD 285 to 305. He was born in Dalmatia, and rose to prominence as a military officer. Diocletian's reign saw a period of peace and prosperity, and he was a major figure in the steady rise of the Roman Empire.

Francis of Assisi.passage: Francis of Assisi (Italian: [fʁɑ̣ns ɔˈsːdʒi, fʁɑ̣nˈz̩]; 25 September 1181 – 3 October 1226) was an Italian Catholic priest, and a founder and prominent member of the Franciscan Order, a mendicant order of friars. He was a preacher of the Gospel, a reformer, and a writer. Francis was born to a wealthy family in Assisi. He was named Giovanni, but his father changed it to Francesco (French for Francis) after the saintly French king Louis IX. Francis's father died in 1226, leaving the family's estate to Francis. Francis was apprenticed to a cloth merchant but gave that up when he joined the Order of Saint Clare. He was soon joined by others who felt called to a religious life. Francis and his followers took a vow to live in poverty and chastity, and to go out to preach the Gospel. They soon attracted followers. Francis and his followers lived a simple life, wearing the clothes they had received from God. Francis preached the Gospel, and his sermons and writings are among the Franciscan treasures. Francis founded the Order of Friars Minor (the Franciscans) in 1210, and was canonized in 1228.

Academy.passage: The Academy is a fictional academy appearing in American comic books published by Marvel Comics, commonly in association with the X-Men. It is a training facility that trains young mutants, and serves as an analogue for Marvel's own X-Men. The Academy is also the name of the primary setting in the X-Men animated series. It was created by Chris Claremont and John Byrne and first appeared in X-Men #45 (July 1975).

The X-Men are a group of mutants who possess superhuman abilities and fight for peace and equality between humans and mutants. Lyceum.passage: Lyceum (ancient Greek: Λύκειον, Lúkéion, "Lyceum" or "Lyceum gymnasium"; Latin: "Liceum" or "Liceium"; Greek: Λυκείον, Lúkeión, "Lyceum") is a school building, usually a large, multi-room complex, in ancient Greece, Rome, and Byzantium. Lyceum schools played an important role in the education of the elite classes. In ancient Greece, the Lyceum was the gymnasium of the ancient Greek city-state of Athens. It was founded in the early 6th century BC by the statesman and reformer Draco and was the first institution in Greece dedicated to the teaching of literature and philosophy. The Lyceum was the site where Socrates taught and gave his famous discourse on the nature of the soul, the "Apology" or "Defense". The Lyceum was also the site of the trial and execution of Socrates, who was sentenced to death for corrupting the youth of Athens and denying the gods of the city. The Lyceum was the site of the first democratic government of Athens, established after the expulsion of the Peisistratidae, when the Alcmeonidae family took over the government of the city. The Lyceum was the site where Plato taught and gave his famous discourse on the forms.

Augustine.passage: Augustine of Hippo (/ˈɔːstʒən/; Latin: [austiˈɛnus] (listen); A.D. 354 – 430) was an influential theologian and Bishop of Hippo Regius in what is now Algeria. He is known for his teachings on grace, free will, predestination, and original sin, which are key elements of Western Christianity. Augustine's views, which were later labelled as Semi-Pelagian, were influential in the development of Western Christian theology.

Evagrius.passage: Evagrius (Greek: Εὐάγριος, Eὐαγρίος; c. 395 – c. 455) also known as Evagrius Ponticus was a Christian theologian who lived in the late 4th century. He was a disciple of the famous Neoplatonist, Ammonius Saccas, who taught that the One (the Monad, the God of the Gnostics) is beyond all being and non-being. Evagrius taught the same doctrine, but added a new element: the soul is capable of attaining the divine, but must purify itself through ascetic practices and prayer. the Roman Republic.passage: The Roman Republic was a political entity of ancient Rome, existing from 509 BC to 27 BC and from 31 BC to 14 AD. During this period, the Roman people was ruled by two consuls, elected annually by the citizens of Rome for a period of one year, and who acted as heads of government and military commanders. The Senate, a body of old and distinguished men, advised the consuls on the administration of the state. The Roman Republic was founded in 509 BC after the overthrow of the monarchy and the establishment of a republic. The founding of the republic was preceded by centuries of political development and many previous attempts to create a republic, dating back to the early days of the Roman Kingdom. The Roman Republic was originally dominated by a wealthy and powerful senatorial class of aristocratic families, which was in control of the executive and judicial branches of the Roman state. Over time, this led to a concentration of power in the senatorial class, which was perceived as a threat to the democratic nature of the Roman state. This led to a series of civil wars between the Roman aristocracy and the plebeians, culminating in the conflict known as the Roman Revolution, in which the Roman Republic was replaced by the Roman Empire, ruled by a monarchical Emperor and his successors.

qae_pairs.question: How long did the Roman Republic last?
qae_pairs.explanation: The Roman Republic lasted from 509 BC to 14 AD.

qae_pairs.explanation: the Roman Republic was replaced by the Roman Empire

He was elected consul five times, and dictator twice, holding the highest offices of state for over forty years, and was one of the most respected figures in Roman history. Confucianism.passage: Confucianism (Kǒngjīng 孔经, "Kǒng" pronunciation: [kɔŋ.ʈʈʂiən]; "Kǒng" meaning "Master Kong" or "Kǒng" meaning "Kǒng" or "Kǒng" meaning "Spring" or "Gate of Spring") is an ethical and philosophical system founded by Kong Qiu (551–479 BC). It was developed during the Spring and Autumn Period and the Warring States Period in ancient Chinese history. Confucianism is an ethical philosophy and humanistic religion based on the teachings of Kong Qiu, a scholar-official, who lived in the early Zhou Dynasty (traditional dates: 1122–255 BCE). It was founded during the Spring and Autumn Period (722–476 BCE) and the Warring States Period (475–221 BCE) of ancient Chinese history. Confucianism is sometimes called the "School of Virtues" or the "School of Humanity" (Chinese: Rén 仁 "humanity").

China.passage: China (simplified Chinese: 中国; traditional Chinese: 中國; pinyin: Zhōngguó), officially the People's Republic of China (PRC), is a unitary sovereign state in East Asia. Ammonites.passage: In 1841, the first ammonite fossil was discovered, and in 1856, the first ammonite was named. The group of extinct marine animals to which ammonites belong is called Ammonoidea. They grew to be about 30 cm (1 ft) long, and had shells with chambers that were arranged in a spiral.

the Hebrew Bible.passage: The Hebrew Bible, also referred to as the Tanakh or the Old Testament, is a collection of sacred texts or canons written in the Hebrew language, forming the Christian Old Testament. The Tanakh consists of 24 books, traditionally attributed to the writers of the Hebrew Bible, spanning the period of approximately 3,000 years of Jewish history, from approximately 1200 BCE to the second half of the 1st century CE. The books are divided into the Torah (Five Books of Moses) and the Nevi'im (Prophets). The first part of the Tanakh, the Torah, is also known by its Hebrew name, "Sefer Torah". This first part is the narrative history of the Hebrews from their departure from Egypt to their entry into the Land of Israel. The Torah consists of the historical books of Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, and Deuteronomy. The Nevi'im, the second part of the Tanakh, consists of the prophetic books of Joshua, Judges, Samuel, Kings, and Isaiah. The books of the Nevi'im are not a chronologically arranged collection of writings, but rather a collection of writings on different topics and from different periods of time. The Nevi'im are sub-divided into the Former Prophets (Joshua, Judges, Samuel and Kings) and the Latter Prophets (Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel and the Twelve Minor Prophets).

qae_pairs.question: What book of the Hebrew Bible contains the story of the Israelites' exodus from Egypt under the leadership of Moses?

the Franciscan Order.passage: The Franciscan Order (Italian: Frati Minori di San Francesco; also called Friars Minor or Minorites), commonly known as the Friars Minor, is a Catholic religious order of enclosed (i.e., not-accepting new members) men, founded by Saint Francis of Assisi in 1209. The order is also known by the names of the two other main branches: the Order of Saint Clare and the Order of Saint Augustine. The Friars Minor is the largest of the three branches, and it is one of only three Catholic religious orders of both sexes (the others being the Augustinian Hermits and the Benedictine Sisters of Perpetual Adoration).

the Order of Friars Minor.passage: The Order of Friars Minor (Latin: Ordo Fratrum Minorum) is a Catholic religious order of friars founded in 1209. It is also known as the Franciscans, and its members are known as Friars Minor, or the Minorites. The order was founded in Rome by Francis of Assisi. It was approved as a religious order of pontifical right by Pope Honorius III in 1223, and received papal sanction for its rule in 1223, 1253 and 1879. It is also known as the Order of the Friars Minor, the Order of the Friars Minors, the Friars Minor, or the Franciscans. The order is also sometimes called the Observants, after its largest branch, the Observant Friars Minor (Latin: Fratres Minores Observantibi, or Friars Minor Observant). The Order of Friars Minor has a worldwide membership of about 25,000.
